ITEM 1. BUSINESS.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - ITEM 1. BUSINESS section of PayPal Holdings, Inc. in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, PayPal has 434 million active accounts across approximately 200 markets.
• In 2024, PayPal processed $1.68 trillion of total payment volume (TPV), an increase of 10% compared to 2023.
• The company had 26.3 billion payment transactions in 2024, an increase of 5% compared to 2023.
• As of December 31, 2023, PayPal had 434 million active accounts, an increase of 2% from the previous year.
• The company's revenue is primarily generated by charging fees for completing payment transactions and other payment-related services.

ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS section in bullet points:

• Cyberattacks and security vulnerabilities could result in serious harm to PayPal's reputation, business, and financial condition.
• The techniques used to attempt to obtain unauthorized or illegal access to systems and information are continuously evolving.
• Unauthorized parties continuously attempt to gain access to PayPal's systems or facilities through various means, including hacking into their systems or those of customers, partners, or vendors.
• Numerous and evolving cybersecurity threats, including advanced and persisting cyberattacks, cyberextortion, distributed denial-of-service attacks, ransomware, spear phishing, and social engineering schemes, are becoming increasingly sophisticated and complex.
• Hostile actors, who may comprise individuals, coordinated groups, sophisticated organizations, or nation state supported entities, may target PayPal due to its name, brand recognition, types of data that customers provide, and widespread adoption and use of its products and services.
• PayPal has experienced cybersecurity incidents in the past, including breaches of security measures, network breaches, and compromise of personally identifiable customer information due to human error, deception, malfeasance, insider threats, system errors, defects, vulnerabilities, or other issues.

ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY section in bullet points:

• The company's Information Security Program is designed to identify, protect, detect, respond to, and recover from cybersecurity threats and incidents.
• The program is guided by National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF) and ISO standards (including ISO 27001).
• The three lines of defense model is used in the Information Security Program, consisting of first line of defense (FLOD), second line of defense (SLOD), and third line of defense (TLOD).
• The Office of the Chief Information Security Officer oversees the company's information, cyber, and technology security.
• Risk assessments are conducted regularly to identify material cybersecurity risks to critical systems and information.
• Regular testing is performed on systems to identify and address potential vulnerabilities.
• A cybersecurity incident response plan is in place, including procedures for responding to cybersecurity incidents.
• 24/7 monitoring and measurement of cybersecurity threats are conducted through the PayPal Cyber Defense Center (CDC).
• External service providers may be used to assess or assist with aspects of security controls.
• An information training and awareness program is provided for employees, contractors, incident response personnel, and senior management.
• A third-party risk management framework is in place to monitor and address risks from cybersecurity incidents involving service providers, suppliers, and vendors.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 2. PROPERTIES section:

• As of December 31, 2024, PYPL owns a total of approximately 70 acres of land.
• Approximately 49 acres of the owned land are located in the United States (U.S.).
• The corporate headquarters occupy approximately 0.7 million square feet of owned space in San Jose, California.
